data.title: Nvidia leads chip stocks lower, investors worry about AI buildout plans
data.description:
Nvidia (NVDA) led chip stocks lower on Thursday despite stellar earnings, as investors seemed to remain concerned about AI buildout plans.

The tech-focused Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) fell around 1.7%. At the same time, the benchmark S&P 500 (SP500) dipped about 1%. The blue-chip Dow (DJI) had declined by 0.4%.

AI chipmaker Nvidia's (NVDA) stock slumped about 5%. On Wednesday, Nvidia (NVDA) not only topped fourth-quarter estimates by a wide margin, but its guidance surprised even the most bullish analysts. 

However, investors seemed to be concerned about the massive AI buildout plans.

"Nvidia shares lost roughly 5% in Thursday morning's trade, as investors remain worried over AI buildout plans. While Nvidia has best in class products and trades at a very reasonable valuation, the market doesn't believe that the industry as a whole has the necessary capital required for such aggressive growth plans," said Seeking Alpha analyst Bill Maurer.

Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) declined around 4%. Broadcom (AVGO) tumbled nearly 6%, while Qualcomm (QCOM) was also in the red on Thursday.

Meanwhile, other AI and networking-related stocks also declined on Thursday. Celestica (CLS) slumped about 6%, while Ciena (CIEN), Lumentum (LITE), and Coherent (COHR) each tumbled around 5%. Arista Networks (ANET) fell roughly 3%, while Cisco (CSCO) dipped about 2%.

Shares of GlobalFoundries (GFS) slumped around 6%, while Lattice Semiconductor (LSCC) fell nearly 5%. Marvell Technology (MRVL), Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM), Intel (INTC), Arm (ARM), and Micron Technology (MU) each declined around 4%. Analog Devices (ADI) fell about 3%, while Texas Instruments (TXN) dipped nearly 1%. 

Chip equipment makers: Lam Research (LRCX) and Applied Materials (AMAT) each slumped around 6%, while ASML (ASML) declined about 5%. KLA (KLAC) fell about 3% on Thursday.

data.title: Cheniere Energy targets $7.25B adjusted EBITDA and 51–53M tonnes LNG production in 2026 while expanding capital returns
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Cheniere Energy, Inc. (LNG) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Jack Fusco, President and CEO, highlighted the company's 10th anniversary of its first export cargo, noting the milestone of nearly 5,000 cargoes delivered and reaffirmed Cheniere’s industry leadership. "We lead the U.S. LNG industry, thanks, first and foremost, to the Cheniere workforce and their steadfast commitment to safety and excellence, which they demonstrate every single day." (President, CEO & Director Jack Fusco)
  • Fusco reported consolidated adjusted EBITDA of approximately $2 billion for Q4 and $6.94 billion for the year, with distributable cash flow of $1.5 billion in Q4 and $5.3 billion for the year. Full-year net income was over $5.3 billion, and 2025 marked a record 670 cargoes produced.
  • The company increased its share repurchase authorization to over $10 billion through 2030, following completion of the previous capital allocation plan ahead of schedule.
  • A new long-term SPA with CPC Corporation of Taiwan for up to 1.2 million tonnes per annum was announced, commencing later in 2026 and running through 2050.
  • Corpus Christi Stage 3 construction is 95% complete, with substantial completion of Trains 3 and 4 in Q4; Trains 5, 6, and 7 are expected to be completed in spring, summer, and fall of 2026, respectively. First LNG was achieved at Train 5 this week.
  • Zach Davis, CFO, stated, "For the fourth quarter and full year 2025, we generated net income of approximately $2.3 billion and $5.3 billion, consolidated adjusted EBITDA of approximately $2 billion and $6.9 billion, and distributable cash flow of approximately $1.5 billion and $5.3 billion, respectively."

Outlook

  • Cheniere introduced its 2026 financial guidance of $6.75 billion to $7.25 billion in consolidated adjusted EBITDA and $4.35 billion to $4.85 billion in distributable cash flow, with $3.10 to $3.40 in per unit distributions at CQP. The guidance reflects higher production but lower spot margins and several new long-term contracts commencing during the year. Management expects production of 51 million to 53 million tonnes of LNG across its two sites.
  • The company forecasts less than 1 million tonnes of open capacity for 2026 and highlighted that a $1 change in market margins would impact EBITDA by less than $50 million for the year.

Financial Results

  • Q4 net income was approximately $2.3 billion, with consolidated adjusted EBITDA of around $2 billion and distributable cash flow of $1.5 billion. For full year 2025, net income was over $5.3 billion, adjusted EBITDA $6.9 billion, and distributable cash flow $5.3 billion.
  • 2025 results were supported by higher LNG volumes, completion of Trains 1–4 at CCL Stage 3, and optimization activities, partially offset by higher O&M costs and a major maintenance turnaround at SPL.
  • The company repurchased over 12.1 million shares for $2.7 billion in 2025 and declared total dividends of $2.11 per share for the year.
  • Cheniere repaid $652 million of long-term debt in 2025 and ended the year with approximately $1.6 billion in consolidated cash.

Q&A

  • Jeremy Tonet, JPMorgan: Asked about Asian demand growth and commercial conversations. Anatol Feygin responded that "we're very constructive on what global LNG demand, primarily driven by Asia is going to look like over the coming decades" and noted ongoing appeal of long-term contract economics.
  • Tonet also asked about weather impacts. Jack Fusco stated, "There wasn't anything major one way or the other... it was a slight positive for us, but nothing material."
  • Spiro Dounis, Citi: Asked about SPA progress and market margins. Feygin indicated all first train expansion capacity is spoken for, with some work remaining for the second. Fusco emphasized customer willingness to pay for reliability.
  • Dounis inquired about nitrogen management. Fusco replied, "We've been able to adjust our operating modes. We've been able to buy and inject certain solvents that are really starting to show some big benefits for us."
  • Theresa Chen, Barclays: Inquired about production fees and demand elasticity. Feygin said production fees are "comfortably above the midpoint" of the $2.50–$3 range but noted broader market economics are below that level.
  • Chen’s follow-up on domestic gas demand was addressed by Fusco, who highlighted Cheniere’s long-term contracts and infrastructure as supporting U.S. production growth.
  • Jean Ann Salisbury, BofA: Asked about CapEx escalation. Fusco stressed focus on lead times over inflation and efforts to replicate previous successful train designs.
  • Michael Blum, Wells Fargo: Asked about the timing of CCL expansions and the new CPC contract, with Feygin stating the latter starts midyear 2026.
  • Jason Gabelman, TD Cowen: Asked about potential upside to volume guidance from early train completion. Davis said, "If all 3 trains were a month early, that's comfortably over $50 million of incremental EBITDA at current margins."
  • John Mackay, Goldman Sachs: Asked about Chinese demand pricing. Feygin estimated China would need $8–$9/MMBtu delivered prices for strong demand growth.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on commercial progress, contract margins, production reliability, and CapEx risks, reflecting a neutral to slightly positive tone. Questions reflected confidence in Cheniere's operational execution but sought clarity on economics and expansion timing.
  • Management maintained a confident and constructive tone in prepared remarks and Q&A, frequently referencing disciplined growth, strong contract coverage, and capital returns. Defensive elements surfaced when discussing market competition and cost pressures, but management emphasized reliability and unique value.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management showed increased confidence, especially regarding contract coverage, capital allocation, and future production growth. Management provided more specific forward guidance and appeared less concerned about operational volatility.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for 2026 is now specific, with higher production targets and a tighter range for open capacity versus the previous quarter’s early estimates.
  • The capital allocation plan was completed ahead of schedule, and the share repurchase program was significantly expanded.
  • Management’s tone shifted from cautious optimism in Q3 2025 to strong confidence in Q4, citing record operational results and successful mitigation of production challenges.
  • Analysts focused more on commercial details and the economics of expansion, while management consistently stressed reliability, contracted cash flow, and accretive growth parameters.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management flagged lower spot margins as a headwind for 2026 and noted that guidance could be impacted by variability in production forecasts, train ramp-up timing, and market margin fluctuations.
  • CapEx escalation and lead times for new projects were cited as ongoing challenges, though mitigated by replicating proven train designs and securing long lead items early.
  • Analysts raised concerns about domestic gas market implications and the ability to maintain premium contract margins amid increasing competition and global supply additions.

Final Takeaway

Cheniere Energy finished 2025 with record LNG production and strong financial results, driven by operational improvements and successful mitigation of feed gas challenges. The company introduced robust 2026 guidance, expects further production records, and expanded its capital return program with a $10 billion share repurchase authorization through 2030. With 95% of capacity contracted and new long-term agreements secured, management expressed strong confidence in sustaining cash flow visibility, disciplined growth, and delivering value to shareholders as it advances major expansion projects and navigates evolving global LNG dynamics.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Amazon's investment into OpenAI could be tied to IPO, AGI: report
data.description:
Amazon's (AMZN) much-discussed potential investment into OpenAI (OPENAI) could be tied, in part, to an initial public offering for the ChatGPT maker or its achievement of artificial general intelligence, The Information reported.

Seattle-based Amazon could initially put $15B into OpenAI, the news outlet added, citing people familiar with the matter. The remaining $35B would come if OpenAI were to go public or if it were to reach AGI, which, so far, has not been definitively defined, the people added.

Previous reports have indicated that Amazon could inject close to $50B into OpenAI over time.

Artificial general intelligence, sometimes also known as general artificial intelligence, has been previously described as the singularity—an event where technology surpasses humanity and becomes irreversible.

Aside from the investment, the discussions between the tech giants have also included OpenAI using Amazon's Trainium chips, the people explained. Amazon Web Services and OpenAI inked a $38B deal in November that would see AWS supply OpenAI with “hundreds of thousands” of Nvidia's (NVDA) GPUs.

Other conversations between the two companies have centered on OpenAI creating models for Amazon that could be used in internal products and services, such as its Alexa voice assistant.

OpenAI is in talks with several tech companies and investors about investing in its latest funding round, including Nvidia. The new funding round could reach $100B and value the company at approximately $800B.

OpenAI and Amazon did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Seeking Alpha.

data.title: Victory Capital offer sparks competition for Janus Henderson
data.description:
Janus Henderson Group (JHG) stock climbed 5.7% to $53.02 in Thursday afternoon trading after Victory Capital Holdings (VCTR) submitted a proposal to buy Janus Henderson Group (JHG) for $57.04 per share in stock and cash.

Janus Henderson (JHG), though, had already agreed to sell itself to Nelson Peltz's Trian Fund Management and General Catalyst Group for $49 per share in cash.

The Victory (VCTR) offer consists of $30 in cash and 0.350 share of VCTR for each share of JHG.  Victory describes its offer as "clearly superior," but it will be up to the Janus Henderson board to determine that.

The Trian/General Catalyst deal requires that two-thirds of shares be voted in favor of the deal, a threshold that will be difficult to reach, CNBC's David Faber said. Note that Trian owns 20.6% of Janus Henderson's (JHG) shares.

"You've got a lot of risk arbs (risk arbitrageurs). They've read the proxy, and they're like… "Hmm, I wonder if someone else may come,'" Faber said. "And there was some encouragement for Victory to potentially show up. And they have."

Faber added that he wasn't able to find out how Trian and General Catalyst will respond to the offer. "But they clearly know they're probably going to have to do something if they want to own the company," the CNBC anchor said. "Or potentially sell to this higher bid."

Victory Capital (VCTR) estimates the deal would produce cost synergies of ~$500M. The potential acquirer said its gross leverage will be 3.5x 2025 EBITDA, excluding synergies, and 2.6x 2025 EBITDA, including the synergies.

data.title: Bentley Systems targets 11%–13% revenue growth in 2026 while expanding AI monetization
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Bentley Systems (BSY) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Gregory Bentley, President & Executive Chairman of the Board, emphasized the durability and visibility of Bentley’s business model, noting, “Our key metric, annual constant currency ARR growth has been reliably sustained in the low-double digits since 2022.” He highlighted that free cash flow margin reached 35% in 2025 and truly free cash flow margin, less stock-based compensation, reached 30%. Bentley reported retiring the maturing 2026 convertible debt, reducing the fully diluted share count by about 3%. He stated, “Having reached a satisfactory target range of about 2x, we have completed delevering since the platform acquisitions and can now allocate more of our cash flow generation towards scaled up programmatic acquisitions.” On AI, Bentley said, “AI is not a risk to be countered but an unprecedented opportunity,” underscoring the company’s positioning as a digital quarterback for infrastructure engineering.
  • CEO Nicholas Cumins outlined the company’s twofold AI strategy: embedding AI into products and instrumenting platforms for user- and partner-built AI workflows. He noted, “Q4 ARR increased 11.5% year-over-year… Net revenue retention was stable at 109%.” Cumins also highlighted the resilience of the Seequent business and continued strong growth in Public Works Utilities, driven by “sustained global infrastructure investment and the standout performance of Bentley Asset Analytics.”
  • CFO Werner Andre reported, “For the full year 2025, total revenues were $1.502 billion, growing 11% on a reported basis and 10% in constant currency… For the fourth quarter, total revenues were $392 million, an increase of 12% reported and 10% in constant currency.” He added, “Our free cash flow generation for the year was very strong, totaling $520 million, up 24% year-over-year.”

Outlook

  • Bentley Systems projects total revenues constant currency growth in the range of 11% to 13% for 2026, translating to $1.685 billion to $1.750 billion at current exchange rates. Subscription revenues, which comprise 92% of the business, are expected to grow 11% to 13% in constant currency. The company expects constant currency ARR growth between 10.5% and 12.5%. Adjusted operating income less operating stock-based compensation is forecast to be between $495 million and $510 million. Free cash flow for 2026 is projected in the range of $500 million to $570 million. Management stated that “our mainstay subscription revenues… are expected to grow between 11% and 13% in constant currency.”

Financial Results

  • For the full year 2025, total revenues reached $1.502 billion, with subscription revenues representing 92% of total revenues. E365 now comprises 45% of subscription revenues. Adjusted operating income less stock-based compensation for the year was $430 million, with a margin of 28.6%. Free cash flow totaled $520 million for the year. The company reported ending Q4 with ARR of $1.462 billion at quarter-end spot rates, and ARR growth rate was 11.5% year-over-year on a constant currency basis.

Q&A

  • Matthew Hedberg, RBC Capital Markets: Asked about elements that could push ARR growth to the higher end of the range and whether AI is a driver. Gregory Bentley responded that “AI is contributing now in the form of asset analytics and faster growth in asset analytics than elsewhere,” but noted the revenue is not yet fully annual recurring due to inspection cycles.
  • Jason Celino, KeyBanc Capital Markets: Asked about leverage and M&A. Gregory Bentley explained, “Now with leverage down… we are expanding our -- where we're open in M&A to beyond asset analytics potentially.”
  • Joseph Vruwink, Robert W. Baird: Asked if growing attention to digital twins is opening the pipeline. Nicholas Cumins stated, “Our products themselves are leveraging the digital twin technology… it's basically happening without the accounts necessarily being aware of it.”
  • Sitikantha Panigrahi, Mizuho: Inquired about macro assumptions. Nicholas Cumins said, “We are assuming for 2026 is remarkably consistent with what we've seen in 2025… the only area where we've seen a slowdown… was really the sector of facilities and commercial facilities.”
  • Kristen Owen, Oppenheimer: Asked about drivers of services revenue recovery. Nicholas Cumins highlighted improvement in IBM Maximo-related services, while Gregory Bentley noted minimal contribution from Asset Analytics acquisitions in services revenue.
  • Jay Vleeschhouwer, Griffin Securities: Inquired about product packaging changes. Nicholas Cumins said, “The new packaging was actually released in Q4… Connect itself is getting very quickly adopted.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed optimism about AI and growth outlook but pressed for clarity on ARR growth drivers and the pace of AI monetization. The tone was generally positive, with some probing on adoption timelines and M&A strategy.
  • Management maintained a confident tone, particularly in discussing AI opportunities and financial robustness. Phrases such as “we are well positioned with a great foundation and strategy” and “we are expanding our -- where we're open in M&A” indicated confidence. During Q&A, responses showed a mix of confidence and careful qualification regarding the pace of AI revenue impact.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, both management and analysts’ tones remained positive, with an increased focus on AI execution and near-term monetization.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • ARR growth strengthened to 11.5% year-over-year in Q4 from 10.5% in Q3. Guidance for 2026 remains consistent with prior outlooks, targeting low-double-digit revenue and ARR growth. Management’s tone on AI shifted from conceptual discussion in Q3 to highlighting tangible asset analytics contributions and monetization strategies in Q4. Analysts maintained a focus on recurring revenue, AI monetization, and M&A capacity. Service revenues are now expected to reaccelerate, driven by Maximo and Asset Analytics, versus flat expectations in Q3.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management acknowledged that asset analytics revenue is not fully annual recurring yet, introducing some variability. Macro risks persist in China and commercial facilities. There is also a deliberate focus on prudent adoption and monetization of AI, reflecting the sector’s regulatory and operational caution. Analysts raised questions about the pace of AI-driven revenue and the impact of macro factors on budgets and sales cycles.

Final Takeaway

Bentley Systems enters 2026 with robust financial fundamentals, consistent revenue growth, and a disciplined approach to expanding both its core subscription business and AI-enabled initiatives. Management projects low-double-digit growth across key metrics and is broadening M&A focus as leverage declines. The company is prioritizing AI integration and asset analytics monetization, with immediate opportunities in operational use cases and longer-term prospects in design optimization. While asset analytics revenue is not yet fully recurring, the company is confident in its strategy to drive durable growth as AI adoption matures.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Perrigo outlines 2026 CORE EPS range of $2.25 to $2.55 as company navigates soft OTC market
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Perrigo Company plc (PRGO) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Patrick Lockwood-Taylor, President, CEO & Director, began by emphasizing Perrigo's "meaningful progress" in 2025, stating, "We are winning with consumers and customers, and that momentum is reflected in the strong market share gains and incremental business we secured with key retailers." He highlighted that the company delivered EPS in line with revised guidance, improved operating income and EPS year-over-year, and made strong progress on the Three-S Plan to simplify, streamline, and strengthen the business.
  • Lockwood-Taylor noted, "Our share gains accelerated throughout the year, reversing years of decline," and pointed out over $100 million in new distribution and competitive takeaways. He reported stabilization in the store brand business and supply in infant formula, and referenced the announced sale of the Dermacosmetics business, expected to close in the second quarter of 2026.
  • The CEO announced the introduction of new reporting segments—Self-care, Specialty Care, and Infant Formula—beginning Q1 2026 to provide "greater clarity into underlying performance."
  • Eduardo Bezerra, Executive VP & CFO, disclosed, "Our 2025 GAAP results include noncash accounting impacts, including a goodwill impairment charge of $1.3 billion," adding that this impairment "does not impact our strategy, cash flows or ability to execute."
  • Bezerra also stated, "We expect proceeds from Dermacosmetics to contribute to debt reduction in the second quarter," and announced a new 2-year operational enhancement program targeting a global workforce reduction of approximately 7% and operational cost reductions, with expected annualized pretax savings of $80 million to $100 million.

Outlook

  • Lockwood-Taylor described 2026 as a "transition year," projecting CORE Perrigo organic net sales growth to range from negative 3.5% to positive 0.5% compared to 2025, and CORE EPS in the range of $2.25 to $2.55.
  • He cautioned that "OTC market consumption to remain negative in the first half of 2026 as consumption so far in 2026 has further weakened," but added, "We expect the environment to improve in the second half."
  • Bezerra explained, "CORE EPS phasing is approximately 30% to 35% in the first half and 65% to 70% in the second half, which is modestly above our typical pattern."
  • The company expects All-In net sales growth of minus 5.5% to minus 1.5%, and All-In EPS in the range of $2 to $2.30, assuming divestiture of Dermacosmetics in Q2.
  • Bezerra indicated, "We expect operating cash flow conversion to remain in the mid-60 percentage range and net leverage to end the year roughly in line with or slightly better than 2025."

Financial Results

  • Lockwood-Taylor reported, "All-In business grew operating income by 2% and EPS by 7%, finishing at $2.75, right in line with our revised guidance. CORE Perrigo operating income was up 7%, with core EPS up 14%."
  • In Q4, "CORE Organic net sales declined 2% in the quarter despite strong share gains. And CORE operating income declined by $4 million or 2%, resulting in CORE EPS of $0.76, a decline of $0.02."
  • Bezerra detailed, "Exiting 2025, we had $532 million of cash on the balance sheet and fourth quarter operating cash flow was $175 million, bringing our total for the year to $239 million. We ended 2025 with a net leverage ratio of 4x."
  • He added, "Fourth quarter core operating income increased 10.3% due to favorable foreign currency."

Q&A

  • Keith Devas, Jefferies: Sought detail on "what's driving that second half improvement" in 2026 and longer-term OTC category stability. Lockwood-Taylor responded that "the great majority of that as being transitory in nature," citing temporary trade-down and lack of price increases, and expects normalization to begin in late Q2 and accelerate in the second half. He added, "about 60% of the value of our innovation is in the second half of this year."
  • Devas followed up on liquidity and leverage, asking if the company has "enough flex to reinvest in the business." Bezerra replied, "Our capital allocation priorities remain unchanged," and expects proceeds from Dermacosmetics to be used for debt reduction, describing 2026 as "a transitory year" for free cash flow but expecting improvement into 2027.
  • Ethan Brown, JPMorgan: Asked about recovery of OTC margins and timing. Bezerra described under-absorption impacts as "transitory in nature," expecting improvement as the market normalizes in the second half and into 2027.
  • Susan Anderson, Canaccord Genuity: Asked which CORE categories are driving negative growth. Lockwood-Taylor noted "preventative categories are typically doing better," while "cough/cold, and particular subsegments of pain, mainly pill dosing" are underperforming. Anderson also queried dividend priorities and leverage goals, with Bezerra stating, "for '26, as we highlighted, we expect that to be in line or slightly better than 2025."
  • Daniel Biolsi, Hedgeye: Sought details on working capital in Infant Formula. Bezerra cited "significant" inventory levels and noted a plan for "low to mid-single-digit net sales plan should help deplete that inventory this year."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed management on the depth and duration of soft market conditions, liquidity, margin recovery, and strategic reviews, signaling a neutral to slightly negative tone especially regarding short-term headwinds and inventory issues.
  • Management's tone during prepared remarks was pragmatic and confident, but during Q&A, both Lockwood-Taylor and Bezerra acknowledged challenges, using phrases like "transitory in nature" and "we expect that to be recovered into 2027," reflecting a measured but realistic outlook.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management maintained a steady tone, but with a sharper focus on cost controls and operational enhancements amid persistent market softness. Analyst sentiment remained cautious, continuing to probe on near-term risks and recovery timing.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Management's 2026 guidance language is more tempered, specifically calling 2026 a "transition year" and explicitly outlining temporary headwinds such as under-absorption and market softness, whereas Q3 emphasized stabilization and the beginnings of recovery.
  • Strategic focus shifted more clearly to cost reduction, operational streamlining, and portfolio optimization, including explicit workforce reduction and the impact of divestitures.
  • Analysts in both quarters concentrated on OTC consumption trends, Infant Formula, and capital allocation, but the current quarter featured more pointed questions about cash flow, leverage, and category-specific drivers.
  • The tone of both management and analysts remained cautious, but current remarks reveal greater visibility and willingness to address structural and operational adjustments.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited continued softness in OTC market consumption, a slow cough and cold season, retailer inventory adjustments, and competitive pressures in Infant Formula as ongoing risks.
  • Bezerra described the $1.3 billion goodwill impairment and potential for further noncash impairment charges up to $350 million as non-operational risks.
  • The company expects "temporary but significant impact from plant under absorption stemming from lower sales volumes," which will weigh on 2026 EPS.
  • Analysts consistently questioned the pace of margin and cash flow recovery, the sustainability of share gains, and the effectiveness of cost-saving measures.

Final Takeaway

Perrigo management emphasized that 2026 will be a transitional year marked by temporary market and operational headwinds, yet highlighted continued market share gains, a robust innovation pipeline, and disciplined cost actions. The company projects CORE EPS in the $2.25 to $2.55 range, expects margin and cash flow improvement as conditions normalize, and remains committed to deleveraging and prioritizing investments in growth and returns to shareholders. The leadership team sees 2027 as a meaningful growth year, underpinned by strategic portfolio moves and operational enhancements completed in 2026.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Montrose targets 10% EBITDA growth and launches $40M share repurchase while expanding AI-driven opportunities in 2026
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Montrose Environmental Group, Inc. (MEG) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Vijay Manthripragada reported "2025 was a record year across every key dimension: revenue, EBITDA, and cash flow." He emphasized that "we delivered full year revenue of $830.5 million and consolidated adjusted EBITDA of $116.2 million, both record highs and both well above the initial guidance we provided at the start of 2025."
  • Manthripragada highlighted organic growth outpacing targets, stating "revenue grew 19.3% versus 2024, driven by organic growth of 12.7%, which meaningfully exceeded our long-term organic growth target of 7% to 9%." All three segments posted solid organic revenue growth despite regulatory uncertainty.
  • Addressing regulatory concerns, Manthripragada stated "the macro and regulatory backdrop for environmental services and solutions remains as constructive as we have seen, and the performance we delivered in 2025 is the clearest possible evidence of that."
  • Demand from sectors such as mining, pharmaceuticals, semiconductors, and technology companies building data centers was called out as a recent growth driver. Manthripragada noted "the air monitoring or water treatment needs for our clients in these sectors has picked up materially and were not part of our outlook 18 months ago."
  • On methane and PFAS regulatory changes, the CEO explained the business is insulated by private sector demand and state-level regulations. He also pointed to the PFAS business as "already a high-margin growth driver across our segments."
  • Manthripragada unveiled a "$40 million share repurchase authorization" and confirmed the company is "in a strong position to begin returning capital directly to shareholders." He also announced a return to acquisitions in 2026, after a previously announced pause.
  • CFO Allan Dicks stated "full year 2025 revenues increased by 19.3% versus 2024, totaling $830.5 million, well above our initial guidance." Dicks noted "consolidated adjusted EBITDA increased 21.3% to $116.2 million, or 14% of revenue, resulting in our third consecutive year of margin expansion."

Outlook

  • Manthripragada introduced 2026 guidance of "$840 million to $900 million in revenue and $125 million to $130 million in consolidated adjusted EBITDA." At the midpoint, this represents "approximately 10% EBITDA growth compared to 2025."
  • The company is targeting "approximately 15% consolidated adjusted EBITDA margins in 2026."
  • "Organic revenue growth of 7% to 9% remains our long-term expectation. And for 2026, we expect to be at the high end of that range."
  • Revenue in the second half of 2026 is expected to be higher than the first half, with "the second half contributing approximately 60% of full year consolidated adjusted EBITDA."
  • Operating cash conversion is expected to be "60%" in 2026, after achieving "93%" in 2025.

Financial Results

  • Dicks reported "fourth quarter revenue increased to $193.3 million compared to $189.1 million in the prior year period."
  • For the full year, "net loss improved to $0.8 million, or $0.14 loss per diluted share compared to a net loss of $62.3 million, or $2.22 net loss per diluted share in 2024."
  • Adjusted net income and diluted EPS for 2025 were $60.7 million and $1.36, respectively.
  • Segment results highlighted the Assessment, Permitting and Response segment with "full year revenue increased 43%, or $92.6 million, to $307.4 million," and Measurement and Analysis segment with "full year revenue grew 9.6% to $245.9 million."
  • Operating cash flow reached $107 million in 2025, a "93% conversion of consolidated adjusted EBITDA."
  • The company exited the year with a leverage ratio of 2.5x and available liquidity of $225 million.

Q&A

  • Timothy Mulrooney, William Blair: Asked about cadence of revenue and EBITDA in 2026. Allan Dicks replied "we expect revenues to be split roughly 50-50 front half/back half" and EBITDA "40% first half, 60% second half." He noted "Q1 is just a very seasonally slow quarter" and emergency response revenue timing can shift quarterly splits.
  • Mulrooney inquired about AI impacts. Manthripragada responded "our work is much more bespoke," and noted "we are already in the process" of using AI for efficiency and new revenue streams, especially in sensor networks and air monitoring. He added "the technology companies that are driving a lot of this activity are Montrose's clients," and AI-driven demand is a "tailwind."
  • Mulrooney asked about new thematics (mining, pharma, semi, data centers). Manthripragada said "GLP-1 manufacturers...are working with us" for PFAS solutions, data center work is already contributing to revenue, and "our water technology business...we expect to grow double digits in '26 compared to '25."
  • James Ricchiuti, Needham: Sought clarity on organic growth drivers. Manthripragada pointed to "our water technology business, which we expect to grow really nicely into the foreseeable future" and ongoing demand in testing and consulting. He described cross-selling as "largely just execution" and cited new commercial talent as a driver.
  • Ricchiuti asked about PFAS revenue. Manthripragada said "it remains about 10% to 15% of our business" with "double-digit growth expected into 2026."
  • Tami Zakaria, JPMorgan: Queried M&A timing and focus. Manthripragada said "nothing imminent" but "expect to close some" small, bolt-on deals in the back half of the year, with focus on testing and consulting.
  • Zakaria asked about a lighter Q1. Dicks confirmed "it is primarily lower emergency response" and some "project timing and tougher comparisons year-over-year in Q1 that lighten as we progress through the year."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on cadence, AI, sector tailwinds, organic growth, PFAS, and M&A; tone remained positive, with constructive and detailed responses from management cited as helpful.
  • Management maintained a confident and optimistic tone, frequently referencing record performance and robust demand. Manthripragada used phrases such as "extremely pleased," "deeply optimistic," and "the confidence we have in our performance."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analysts continued to probe about segment drivers and strategic execution, but the tone was slightly more positive in Q4, reflecting strong year-end results and clear guidance. Management sustained a consistent level of confidence, now bolstered by actual record outcomes and the initiation of share repurchases.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • 2026 guidance was introduced with a clear revenue and EBITDA target, compared to Q3's more general outlook for at least $125 million in EBITDA.
  • The company advanced its share repurchase program in Q4, a new development versus Q3 where capital allocation focused primarily on organic investments.
  • Management's tone remained optimistic in both quarters, but Q4 was marked by even greater confidence as all 2025 record targets were exceeded.
  • Analysts shifted from questions about wind-down impacts in renewables (Q3) to more forward-looking inquiries on AI, sector opportunities, and M&A timing (Q4).
  • Key metrics such as organic growth, margin expansion, and cash flow strengthened further in Q4, with leverage and liquidity improving sequentially.
  • Strategic focus shifted from balance sheet simplification to resuming acquisitions and share repurchases in Q4.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management addressed ongoing regulatory uncertainty, emphasizing that "regulatory volatility and uncertainty creates meaningful headwinds for Montrose" is not supported by results, as "the macro and regulatory backdrop...remains as constructive as we have seen."
  • Potential headwinds discussed included timing and unpredictability of emergency response revenue, continued wind-down of renewables, and project timing impacts in early 2026.
  • Analysts questioned the impact of AI on business defensibility, but management indicated the company is "much more insulated from those dynamics" than traditional engineering and design firms.
  • Exposure to U.S. federal government remains low, with less than 3% of revenue, minimizing direct policy risk.

Final Takeaway

Montrose Environmental delivered record revenue, EBITDA, and cash flow in 2025, achieving growth well beyond initial guidance and expanding margins for the third straight year. The company sees robust organic growth continuing into 2026, supported by strong demand from private sector clients in sectors like mining, pharma, and technology. Strategic priorities for 2026 include high-end organic revenue growth, margin expansion, strong cash conversion, and renewed focus on M&A and share repurchases, with $40 million authorized for buybacks. Management remains deeply optimistic, citing a constructive regulatory backdrop, resilient private sector demand, and a robust pipeline of opportunities across geographies and end markets.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Teladoc upgraded at BofA on BetterHelp prospects
data.description:
Teladoc Health (TDOC) added ~14% on Thursday after its consensus-beating Q4 2025 results, while Bank of America upgraded the telehealth provider, citing the prospects of its mental health business, BetterHelp.

On Wednesday after the close, the New York-based health tech reported $642.3M in revenue, exceeding the consensus by $6.9M, as its Integrated Care segment generated $409.1M with ~5% YoY growth even as BetterHelp revenue fell ~7% YoY to $233.2M.

However, according to BofA analyst Allen Lutz, BetterHelp’s marketing intensity would decline, and its margins would improve as it transitions from a direct-to-consumer model to insurance coverage, a strategy followed by its rival Talkspace (TALK).

Lutz pointed out that Talkspace’s (TALK) EBITDA margins have improved to 11.5% at the midpoint of the 2026 outlook from (9%) in 2023 as it pivoted to insurance coverage from being a DTC platform.

“Assuming that BetterHelp can transition 50-60% of its revenue to insurance coverage by 2028 would support an enterprise value of $1.2B (at 2.5x revenue), more than TDOC’s entire valuation today before including Integrated Care and Livongo,” Lutz wrote.

He upgraded Teladoc (TDOC) to Buy from Neutral and reaffirmed his $7 price target on the stock.

data.title: Software job postings pick up Y/Y even as AI haunts the market
data.description:
Hiring says one thing, stocks another.

Software stocks (IGV) have been selling off in the past year as market participants fret over industry-wide AI disruption, yet job postings for software roles are running higher, according to Indeed data. 

Indeed's gauge for software development job postings bounced to 71.4 at of Feb. 20 from 64.0 a year earlier, signaling investor anxiety about AI may be running ahead of what high-frequency hiring data show. Still, the improvement comes off depressed levels, staying well below their 2022 peak of over 230 and under the pre-pandemic baseline of about 100.

Y/Y, software stocks (IGV) dropped 16%, although some analysts have called the move overdone and pointed to signs of a bottom. IGV's top-five holdings are Microsoft (MSFT), Palantir (PLTR), Oracle (ORCL), Salesforce (CRM) and Intuit (INTU).

Other software ETFs: (IGPT), (XSW), and (AOTS).

data.title: Essential Utilities reaffirms 5%-7% EPS growth target through 2027 as merger with American Water advances
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Essential Utilities (WTRG) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Chairman and CEO Christopher Franklin highlighted the overwhelming shareholder support for the company's merger with American Water, stating, "nearly 95% of the shares voted were in favor of the transaction." Franklin emphasized the "record speed" of shareholder approval and noted that all seven required state filings were completed by year-end 2025. He added, "we continue to believe that we will close the transaction in the first quarter of 2027."
  • Franklin reported 2025 earnings per share of $2.20, which he described as "above our guidance range of $2.07 to $2.11." He also underscored the company's record $1.4 billion capital investment in regulated infrastructure for the year and three municipal acquisitions completed in 2025.
  • Dividend growth was also addressed, with a 5.25% increase in the quarterly dividend in July, marking the 35th increase in 34 years and 80 consecutive years of paying dividends.
  • The CEO noted operational achievements, including the continued execution of the $450 million PFAS capital plan and the installation of over 50 advanced treatment systems, as well as reaching the 100,000 Intelis meter milestone in the natural gas segment.
  • Franklin emphasized that merger activities did not detract from operational goals, stating, "our work on the merger did not distract us from our core operational goals and obligations to our customers and that will most certainly continue through 2026."
  • Executive VP & CFO Daniel Schuller reported, "revenues increased $388.5 million or 18.6% from about $2.1 billion a year ago to nearly $2.5 billion this year." Schuller also pointed out, "The $2.20 for 2025 represents significant growth over the $1.97 of non-GAAP income per share in 2024."
  • Schuller discussed nonrecurring items, including favorable regulatory asset adjustments, insurance proceeds, and merger-related expenses. He stated, "even excluding these onetime items, both good and bad, we still had strong financial performance that would have exceeded our range."

Outlook

  • The company reaffirmed its "5% to 7% multiyear earnings per share guidance through 2027 from the adjusted non-GAAP 2024 and earnings per share of $1.97," per Franklin. This guidance includes acquisitions expected to close in 2026 but excludes the DELCORA transaction.
  • Franklin stated, "regulated infrastructure investments are expected to be $1.7 billion" in 2026.
  • Schuller recommended applying the 5% to 7% CAGR to the 2024 non-GAAP income per share of $1.97 for a better sense of 2026 performance, given the impact of nonrecurring items in 2025.

Financial Results

  • Essential Utilities reported full-year 2025 GAAP EPS of $2.20, with Schuller noting it was "above our guidance range of $2.07 to $2.11 due to nonrecurring benefits."
  • Revenues grew to nearly $2.5 billion, driven by $177.6 million in regulatory recoveries, $126.8 million in increased purchased gas costs, and $57.2 million from air gas volumes. Customer growth contributed $5.6 million, while lower water volumes reduced revenue by $8.6 million.
  • O&M expenses rose by $52.3 million, due to higher employee-related costs, increased Universal Services Rider expenses, and water production cost increases. Merger-related expenses were also noted.
  • Regulatory recoveries completed in 2025 totaled $101.5 million of incremental annualized revenue, with $92.6 million from water and wastewater and the remainder from gas.

Q&A

  • Paul Zimbardo, Jefferies: Asked if non-GAAP 2025 EPS was quantified with all adjustments. Daniel Schuller: "No, we didn't specifically, we just gave you kind of the nonrecurring items there, both sort of positive items and then we noted the transaction costs as well."
  • Zimbardo: Inquired about timing for the next round of Pennsylvania rate cases. Schuller: Indicated a likely continuation of a "2-year cadence" for filings.
  • Zimbardo: Questioned the tweak in language regarding credit metrics. Schuller: "We should be above that 12% threshold for Moody's and for S&P. So we feel good about those credit metrics."
  • Travis Miller, Morningstar: Asked if regulatory activity could be combined with merger approval proceedings. Franklin: "They are separate dockets and will be adjudicated separately in each case." Schuller: "We don't see those being combined Travis."
  • Miller: Sought clarification on the company's role in the Chester bankruptcy process. Franklin explained the context of the Supreme Court's ruling, the DELCORA transaction, and potential negotiations for city assets.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analyst tone was neutral, focusing on clarification of non-GAAP adjustments, regulatory cadence, credit metrics, and merger process logistics.
  • Management maintained a confident and slightly positive tone in prepared remarks, emphasizing strong results, dividend growth, and successful infrastructure investments. In Q&A, answers were straightforward, with Schuller showing confidence in credit metrics and Franklin providing detailed explanations about regulatory and bankruptcy developments.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone remained confident, while analyst engagement increased due to the return of live Q&A, shifting from the prior quarter's scripted remarks.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter saw the completion of all seven state filings for the American Water merger and a record-setting shareholder approval process.
  • Full-year financial results were reported, whereas the previous quarter focused on year-to-date performance and projections.
  • Dividend growth and capital investment figures were reaffirmed, with 2026 infrastructure investment expectations increased to $1.7 billion (from $1.4 billion in 2025).
  • Management sustained a confident outlook, while analyst focus shifted toward regulatory timing, credit metrics, and merger logistics, reflecting an increased interest in the merger's progression.
  • The return of live Q&A in this quarter allowed for more direct analyst challenges and clarifications compared to the previous quarter's prepared remarks only.

Risks and Concerns

  • Regulatory approval timing for the American Water merger remains a key challenge, with Franklin acknowledging, "I may not be able to promise this regulatory approval phase will proceed in the same record speed as our shareholder approval."
  • The ongoing bankruptcy process in the city of Chester and its potential impact on the DELCORA transaction was highlighted, with Franklin stating the company is "closely monitoring the receiver's next move."
  • Ongoing national and state discussions around affordability and their potential impact on customer bills were acknowledged, with management reiterating a balanced approach to investments and operating costs.

Final Takeaway

Management emphasized that Essential Utilities delivered a strong 2025 performance, exceeding its EPS guidance with robust revenue growth and record infrastructure investments while advancing the merger with American Water. The company reaffirmed its 5% to 7% EPS growth target through 2027, highlighted its ability to balance operational execution with major strategic initiatives, and reiterated its commitment to regulatory compliance, customer affordability, and maintaining strong credit metrics as it enters a pivotal phase leading up to the anticipated merger.
